   85M presenting with chest pain, found to have left main disease.
   # CORONARIES: Initially presented with concern for unstable angina;
   ruled out by cardiac enzymes; ECG difficult to interpret in setting of
   LBBB.  Medically managed overnight with heparin gtt, nitro gtt, ASA,
   BB, statin. Caridac cath today showed LMCA disease. CT surgery has
   evaluated patient.
   - Continue ASA, heparin gtt

   - CT surgeyr aware; if patient has persistent chest pain or
   decompensates, will do emergent CABG

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old male who presented with chest pain and was found to have left main coronary artery disease. He was medically managed overnight with heparin, nitroglycerin, aspirin, beta-blocker, and statin therapy. A cardiac catheterization revealed LMCA disease, and CT surgery has evaluated the patient.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure of 112/48 mmHg, heart rate of 58 bpm, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 98% on room air. Physical examination shows no fever, oriented and with appropriate mood and affect, sclera anicteric, right pupil 3mm --> 2mm and left faintly reactive, extraocular movements intact, supple neck with jugular venous pressure of 8 cm, regular heart rhythm with a systolic murmur at the left sternal border, clear lungs, soft and non-tender abdomen, 2+ bilateral edema, and a 4x3cm tan discoloration on the right buttock that blanches, intact skin, and no rashes.

Laboratory results show normal white blood cell count, hemoglobin, platelet count, sodium, potassium, and glucose levels, but slightly low hematocrit and elevated creatinine levels. Other labs are within normal range.

The assessment and plan include the following:

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is an 85-year-old male presenting with chest pain and found to have left main coronary artery disease on cardiac catheterization. The patient also experienced a right anterior cerebral artery (ACA) cerebrovascular accident (CVA), likely embolic in nature. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a blood pressure ranging from 112/48 to 153/94 mmHg and a heart rate between 50-60 beats per minute. 

The physical examination reveals no acute changes in the head, neck, respiratory system, or abdomen. However, there is evidence of bilateral lower extremity edema and a tan-colored, blanching area on the right buttock, which is likely a prior decubitus ulcer site. Neurological examination shows decreased strength on the left side, particularly in the foot and leg. 

Laboratory results indicate an elevated white blood cell count of 7.9 K/uL, a decreased hemoglobin level of 12.4 g/dL, and a platelet count of 129. Electrolyte levels are within normal ranges, except for a slightly elevated potassium level of 5.2 mEq/L. Imaging studies reveal loss of gray/white matter differentiation in the medial right frontal lobe, suggesting a possible acute infarction, which requires further evaluation through magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).

The patient's current plan involves continuing aspirin, heparin gtt, starting integr

   coronary artery disease who presented with angina, transferred to the
   CCU after found to have left main coronary artery disease on cath no
   s/p stroke.
   24 Hour Events:
   The patient's neuro findings are improving.  He was able to move his
   left toes slightly and his left arm, although it is still weaker than
   the right side.  He seems to have some neglect - when you ask him to
   lift his arms, he will only lift his right arm until you ask him
   specifically to lift his left arm.  Neuro feels that he has completed
   his stoke and has no further recs regarding BP goals.  They rec
   warfarin for at least 3 months after he is off the heparin gtt and for
   him to f/u with them as an outpatient in 3 months.  He is cleared by
   neuro to get out of bed and work with PT.  His SBP were in the low
   100's after his lopressor so his dose was decreased to 12.5 mg [**Hospital1 **]
   (from 25).  He was started on an integrellin gtt yesterday.  He was
   advanced to a cardiac diet.  Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2830**] and the family discussed
   options regarding treatment for his coronary artery disease and decided
   to procede with medical management at this time and defer surgery given
   his recent stroke.
   This am the patient denies chest pain, SOB, pain, or other complaints.

   - Will have the patient wear compression stockings to decrease his
   lower extremity edema.
   - No diuresis for now given his low SBP.
   # RHYTHM: Sinus bradycardia on telemetry, however the patient has a

   - Continue telemetry.
   - Patient with need 2 week long monitor as an outpatient to monitor for

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old man with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease. He presented with angina and was found to have left main coronary artery disease during cardiac catheterization. He also suffered a stroke, specifically an acute right anterior cerebral artery infarct and multiple small infarcts. His left-sided hemiparesis has improved, but he still remains weaker on the left side. The neurologist feels that he has completed his stroke. The patient's vital signs are stable, and he is being managed medically for his coronary artery disease, as surgery poses a high risk due to his recent stroke. He will continue taking aspirin, metoprolol at a decreased dose, and a high-dose statin. He will also start warfarin for at least three months after discontinuing heparin and integrin. The patient's low blood pressure is being monitored, and he will follow up with cardiology for further evaluation. He has shown improvement in his neurologic findings, and the neurologist recommends outpatient follow-up in three months. The patient will undergo physical therapy and occupational therapy. The plan is to aim for a blood pressure above 130 mmHg, monitor his carotid ultrasound, keep his blood glucose below 150 mg/dL, and monitor his PT/PTT/INR levels. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): Due to immobility and prolonged bed rest, the patient is at an increased risk of developing blood clots in the deep veins of his legs.
2. Pulmonary Embolism (PE): If the patient develops DVT, there is a risk that a clot may dislodge and travel to the lungs, causing a potentially life-threatening condition.
3. Stroke: The patient's recent stroke increases his risk of having another one. Close monitoring and management of risk factors such as hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and hyperlipidemia are crucial.
4. Cardiac Arrhythmias: The patient has a history of sinus bradycardia and paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Monitoring and treatment for arrhythmias are important to prevent complications.
5. Infection: Prolonged hospitalization and invasive procedures increase the risk of developing hospital-acquired infections, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP).
6. Pressure Ulcers: Immobility and decreased sensation can increase the risk of developing pressure ulcers, particularly at sites of pressure and friction.
7. Respiratory Complications: The patient's baseline lung function may be compromised due to age and underlying conditions, increasing the risk of respiratory complications such as atelectasis or pneumonia.

   85M presenting with chest pain, found to have left main disease on
   cath, complicated by a Rt ACA CVA and multiple other small infarcts,
   likely embolic.
   # CVA.  Likely embolic secondary to plaque embolus from his aorta
   during the cardiac cath.  Official MRI reports show an acute Rt ACA
   infarct and multiple small infarcts in his right parietal, right medial
   occipital, left parietal, and left frontal regions.  Neuro feels that
   he has completed his stroke.  His left-sided hemiparesis has improved
   somewhat throughout the day, however he still remains weaker on his
   left side.

   and was ruled out by cardiac enzymes; ECG difficult to interpret in
   setting of LBBB.  Cardiac cath showed LMCA disease.   CABG was
   considered however given his recent stroke and the risk of open-heart
   surgery both the surgeons and the family feel it would be better to
   proceed with medical management at this time.

   his HR has been in the 50

   - Once he recovers from the acute event, can consider continue medical
   management vs CABG vs cath with stent placement for his left main stem
   partial blockage.

   extremity edema on exam, however this is most likely due to venous
   insufficiency.
   - Will have the patient wear compression stockings to decrease his
   lower extremity edema.
   - No diuresis for now given his low SBP.
   # RHYTHM: Sinus bradycardia on telemetry, however the patient has a
   reported history of PAF (patient denies).
   - Continue telemetry.
   - Patient with need 2 week long monitor as an outpatient to monitor for
   a.fib as this would change the length of treatment with coumadin.  If
   the patient is found to have a.fib, will need lifelong coumadin
   therapy.

   monitor.

Summary:
Summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient is an 85-year-old man with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease. He presented with angina and was found to have left main coronary artery disease during a cardiac catheterization procedure. The patient experienced a stroke and multiple small infarcts in his brain, likely due to an embolic event during the cardiac catheterization.

The patient's neurological findings are improving, with some left-sided neglect and weakness. He is able to move his left toes and arm, although his left arm is weaker than his right. The neurologist believes that he has completed his stroke and has no further recommendations regarding blood pressure goals. The patient is cleared to get out of bed and work with physical therapy.

The patient is currently on warfarin for at least 3 months after he is off heparin and will follow up with the neurologist as an outpatient in 3 months. He is also started on an integrellin gtt yesterday. He was advanced to a cardiac diet. The patient and his family decided to proceed with medical management for his coronary artery disease and defer surgery given his recent stroke.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Cardiac complications: The patient has a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease, which increases his risk for future cardiac events such as angina, myocardial infarction, or heart failure.

2. Neurological complications: The patient has already experienced a stroke and

   1. Acute right anterior cerebral artery territorial infarct.
   2. Tiny small areas of slow diffusion in the right parietal, right
   medial occipital, left parietal and the left frontal regions indicate

   Assessment and Plan
   85M presenting with chest pain, found to have left main disease on
   cath, c/b R ACA CVA, likely embolic.
   # CORONARIES: Initially presented with concern for unstable angina;
   ruled out by cardiac enzymes; ECG difficult to interpret in setting of
   LBBB.  Caridac cath today showed LMCA disease. CT surgery has evaluated
   patient.  Given anginal symptoms and poor correlation w/ LMCA lesion
   etiologically (e.g. thrombosis of LM should theoretically lead to
   cardiogenic shock), will reassess the risk profile for LMCA ulcerated
   lesion, discuss w/ family, CT surgery.  [**Hospital 3379**] medical therapy.
   - Continue ASA, heparin gtt,
   - Start integrillin IV gtt
   - Holding nitro gtt given CVA, if SBP > 160 or pt. becomes sx will
   restart.
   - continue metoprolol, high dose statin
   - CT surgeyr aware, will review films, restratify risk and discuss w/
   family.  For now, will hold off on Plavix given possible CABG on
   Monday.
   - F/U carotid U/S.
   # CVA.  Likely embolic, but can not r/o ischemic given HTN in ED/Floor
   (per nursing report), now improving L sided strength.  No ICH.  Not
   candidate for tPA given timing > 3hrs and MERSI retrieval given  > 5hrs
   and size of infarct respectively.  Medical management.
   - Per balance between Neuro recs (autoregulate, SBP < 180 and > 120)
   and decreasing cardiac demand, will maintain SBP 120-160 range for
   now.
   - F/[**Location **] MRI/A
   - F/u carotid U/S.
   - Will consider TEE to eval for cardiac thrombosis
   - BG < 150, HISS
   - appreciate neuro recs, will f/u.
   - PT/OT
   # PUMP: Echo with low-normal EF 50-55% and LVH.  Pt. volume overloaded,
   R sides failure.
   - Will hold off on diuresis given BP goals for now
   # RHYTHM: Sinus bradycardia; reported history of PAF (patient denies).
   In sinus on Tele.  Will monitor
   # ANEMIA: Hct slightly down, 39 to 34 post cath.  Stable.
   - Follow daily and transfuse if <30
   # THROMBOCYTOPENIA: 130s-140s. Low before heparin.  Continue to
   monitor.
   # SPINAL STENOSIS:
   - Surgery delayed until cardiac disease
   - Pain control with oxycodone/acetaminphen
   # HYPERTENSION:
   - Holding  ACE, CCB,
   - continue Metoprolol
   - Nitro gtt prn pressure as above.
   # LUNG NODULE: See on CXR as incidental finding, no priors for
   comparison.
   - Will need CT for further eval but will hold off for now, will need
   f/u as OP.
   # RIGHT BUTTOCK PRIOR DECUB ULCER SITE: Patient reports this is site of
   prior decub which occured during hip fracture surgery.  Per his report,
   was difficult to heal.
   - Skin care; if worsens, wound consult

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

- The patient is an 85-year-old man with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease.
- He presented with angina and was found to have left main coronary artery disease during cardiac catheterization, which resulted in a right anterior cerebral artery stroke and multiple small infarcts.
- The patient's left-sided hemiparesis has improved, but he still remains weaker on his left side.
- He has been started on Coumadin due to the embolic nature of his stroke and will need it for at least 3 months.
- Carotid ultrasound has been scheduled for today.
- The patient will follow up with an outpatient stroke clinic in 3 months.
- Coronary artery disease management includes continuing aspirin, increasing Metoprolol to 12.5 mg, continuing high-dose statin, and restarting ACE inhibitor as tolerated by blood pressures.
- The option of considering CABG for his left main stem partial blockage will be evaluated once he recovers from the acute event.
- Pump function shows a low-normal ejection fraction of 50-55% and left ventricular hypertrophy.
- The patient has lower extremity edema, likely due to venous insufficiency, and will be advised to wear compression stockings to decrease edema.
- Gentle diuresis with IV lasix will be initiated and followed up with electrolyte levels.
- Rhythm management includes monitoring for atrial fibrillation, especially since the patient has a reported history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation.
- Anemia and thrombocytopenia are stable, and the patient's spinal stenosis pain will be managed with acetaminophen.
- Hypertension is currently being managed with a decreased dose of Metoprolol due to hypotension.
- A lung nodule seen on CXR will require further evaluation with CT at a later date.
- The patient has a prior decub ulcer site on his right buttock, which will be monitored for any worsening and may require wound consultation if necessary.
- The patient's ICU care includes cardiac healthy diet, glycemic control, and stress ulcer prophylaxis.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Stroke recurrence: Given the patient's history of stroke and the presence of left main coronary artery disease, there is a risk of another stroke occurring.
2. Bleeding complications: With the initiation of Coumadin therapy, there is a risk of bleeding complications, such as gastrointestinal bleeding or intracranial hemorrhage.
3. Hypotension: The patient's current low systolic blood pressure requires careful monitoring and adjustment of antihypertensive medications.
4. Ventricular arrhythmias: The patient's history of coronary artery disease and left ventricular hypertrophy increases the risk of ventricular arrhythmias.
5. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT):

   85M presenting with chest pain, found to have left main disease on
   cath, complicated by a Rt ACA CVA and multiple other small infarcts,
   likely embolic.
   # CVA.  Likely embolic secondary to plaque embolus from his aorta
   during the cardiac cath.  Official MRI reports show an acute Rt ACA
   infarct and multiple small infarcts in his right parietal, right medial
   occipital, left parietal, and left frontal regions.  Neuro feels that
   he has completed his stroke.  His left-sided hemiparesis has improved
   somewhat throughout the day, however he still remains weaker on his
   left side.
   - Will aim for SBP > 130.

   - Patient will need coumadin for at least 3 months given the embolic
   nature of his stoke.
   - Will have the patient patient f/u in the outpatient stroke clinic in
   3 months.

   and was ruled out by cardiac enzymes; ECG difficult to interpret in
   setting of LBBB.  Cardiac cath showed LMCA disease.   CABG was
   considered however given his recent stroke and the risk of open-heart
   surgery both the surgeons and the family feel it would be better to
   proceed with medical management at this time.

Summary:
The patient is an 85-year-old man with a history of hypertension and coronary artery disease who presented with angina. He was found to have left main coronary artery disease during cardiac catheterization and experienced a right anterior cerebral artery stroke (Rt ACA CVA) and multiple other small infarcts, likely embolic. 

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.2°C, heart rate of 66 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 139/55 mmHg to 150/67 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. His physical examination reveals a first-degree AV block, a systolic murmur at the left sternal border, crackles at the lung bases, bilateral lower extremity edema, and normal neurologic examination except for left-sided neglect and weakness in the left leg. 

Laboratory results show elevated levels of potassium (K+), sodium (Na+), chloride (Cl-), bicarbonate (HCO3-), blood urea nitrogen (BUN), creatinine (Cr), glucose, and leukocyte count (WBC). The patient's hemoglobin (Hb), hematocrit (Hct), and platelet count (Plt) are within normal limits. 

The patient's plan includes aiming for a systolic blood pressure (SBP) greater than 130 mmHg, following up on carotid ultrasound, maintaining blood glucose levels below
